bibliography.source_title: Aqueous-phase mechanism for secondary organic aerosol formation from isoprene: application to the southeast United States and co-benefit of SO2 emission controls
bibliography.source_authors: Marais, E. A., Jacob, D. J., Jimenez, J. L., Campuzano-Jost, P., Day, D. A., Hu, W., Krechmer, J., Zhu, L., Kim, P. S., Miller, C. C., Fisher, J. A., Travis, K., Yu, K., Hanisco, T. F., Wolfe, G. M., Arkinson, H. L., Pye, H. O. T., Froyd, K. D., Liao, J., McNeill, V. F.
bibliography.key_findings: Isoprene SOA formation via IEPOX pathway contributes 58% of isoprene SOA under low-NOx conditions. Mean SOA mass yield of 3.3% from isoprene oxidation. Strong relationship between IEPOX SOA and sulfate aerosol due to aerosol acidity effects.

bibliography.source_title: Multiple pathways for the formation of secondary organic aerosol in the North China Plain in summer
bibliography.source_authors: Gu, Y., Huang, R.-J., Duan, J., Xu, W., Lin, C., Zhong, H., Wang, Y., Ni, H., Liu, Q., Xu, R., Wang, L., Li, Y. J.
bibliography.key_findings: SOA formation via photochemistry (Ox-initiated) dominated daytime with 0.8 µg/m³/h growth rate. Aqueous-phase SOA formation significant during high-RH periods with 0.6 µg/m³/h nighttime growth rate. Photochemistry in aqueous phase also non-negligible (0.6 µg/m³/h).

bibliography.source_title: Effect of clouds on photolysis and oxidants in the troposphere
bibliography.source_authors: Tie, X., Madronich, S., Walters, S., Zhang, R., Rasch, P., Collins, W.
bibliography.key_findings: Clouds increase global mean OH concentration by ~20%. Photolysis rates J[O3], J[CH2O], J[NO2] enhanced by 12-13% due to clouds. Tropospheric O3 concentrations increase by 8% due to cloud effects on photolysis.

bibliography.source_title: Secondary organic aerosol formation in cloud droplets and aqueous particles (aqSOA): a review of laboratory, field and model studies
bibliography.source_authors: Ervens, B., Turpin, B. J., Weber, R. J.
bibliography.key_findings: aqSOA might contribute almost as much mass as gasSOA to the SOA budget. Highest contributions from biogenic VOC emissions in presence of anthropogenic NOx at high RH and cloudiness. Cloud/fog processing produces dicarboxylic acids and humic-like substances.

bibliography.source_title: Re-assessing hydroxyl radical chemistry in the atmosphere: Instrument interferences may explain previous measurement discrepancies
bibliography.source_authors: Price, P., Bottorff, B., Jenkins, J., Brune, W. H., Stevens, P. S.
bibliography.key_findings: OH radical production primarily driven by photolysis of ozone and HONO. OH oxidation of VOCs leads to peroxy radical formation and subsequent SOA production. Strong correlation between OH concentrations and ozone production.

bibliography.source_title: Monoterpenes are the largest source of summertime organic aerosol in the southeastern United States
bibliography.source_authors: Zhang, H., Yee, L. D., Lee, B. H., Curtis, M. P., Worton, D. R., Isaacman-VanWertz, G., et al.
bibliography.key_findings: Monoterpene SOA accounts for ~50% of summertime fine OA. NOx processing enhances monoterpene SOA mass. Both daytime OH oxidation and nighttime NO3 oxidation contribute to MTSOA formation.

relationships.description: Solar UV radiation photolyzes O3 to produce OH radicals, which oxidize VOCs to form SOA contributing to PM2.5
relationships.mechanism: Solar UV radiation (wavelengths 300-400 nm) photolyzes ozone (O3) to produce excited oxygen atoms O(1D), which react with water vapor to form hydroxyl radicals (OH). OH radicals oxidize volatile organic compounds (VOCs) including isoprene and monoterpenes, producing semi-volatile oxidation products that partition to the particle phase as secondary organic aerosol (SOA), contributing to PM2.5 mass.

normalized.interpretation: Lower solar zenith angle means more direct UV radiation reaching surface
Allows sufficient UV penetration for photolysis
Biogenic VOC emissions from vegetation required

conditions.original_text: Water vapor present for OH production

normalized.interpretation: H2O required for O(1D) + H2O → 2OH reaction

relationships.source_title: Re-assessing hydroxyl radical chemistry in the atmosphere
relationships.source_authors: Price, P., Bottorff, B., Jenkins, J., Brune, W. H., Stevens, P. S.
relationships.source_quote: Production of OH in the daytime troposphere is primarily driven by photolytic processes such as the photolysis of ozone and subsequent reaction of excited oxygen atoms (O1D) with water vapor, or the photolysis of nitrous acid (HONO) to directly form OH.
relationships.notes: OH radical is the primary daytime oxidant controlling SOA formation rates

relationships.description: Solar radiation drives Ox-initiated SOA formation dominating daytime organic aerosol production
relationships.mechanism: Solar radiation drives photochemical reactions producing Ox (O3 + NO2), which initiates VOC oxidation. Under high-Ox conditions (65.1 ± 20.4 ppb), efficient SOA formation from photochemistry (Ox-initiated SOA) dominates daytime organic aerosol production with an average growth rate of 0.8 µg/m³/h, contributing 65% to total organic aerosol during daytime.

normalized.interpretation: Ox = O3 + NO2, threshold for efficient photochemical SOA formation
Photochemistry requires solar radiation

conditions.original_text: Summer season with high photochemical activity

normalized.interpretation: Maximum solar radiation and photochemical activity

relationships.source_title: Multiple pathways for the formation of secondary organic aerosol in the North China Plain in summer
relationships.source_authors: Gu, Y., Huang, R.-J., Duan, J., et al.
relationships.source_quote: The photochemical pathway is the most important under high-Ox (i.e., O3 + NO2) conditions (65.1 ± 20.4 ppb). The efficient SOA formation from photochemistry (Ox-initiated SOA) dominated the daytime (65 % to OA), with an average growth rate of 0.8 µg/m³/h.
relationships.notes: Quantitative field measurements from North China Plain summer campaign

metadata.quantitative_effect: 0.8 µg/m³/h SOA growth rate, 65% of daytime OA

relationships.description: Isoprene oxidation via IEPOX pathway produces SOA through acid-catalyzed reactive uptake
relationships.mechanism: Isoprene is oxidized by OH radicals under low-NOx conditions, producing isoprene epoxydiols (IEPOX). IEPOX undergoes acid-catalyzed reactive uptake onto aqueous acidic aerosol particles, forming isoprene-derived SOA. This pathway contributes 58% of total isoprene SOA with a mean mass yield of 3.3% from isoprene oxidation.

normalized.interpretation: ISOPO2 + HO2 pathway dominates over ISOPO2 + NO pathway
Acid catalysis required for IEPOX reactive uptake
High RH needed for aerosol liquid water content

conditions.original_text: Sulfate aerosol present (enhances acidity and volume)

normalized.interpretation: Sulfate provides acidity and aerosol volume for IEPOX uptake

relationships.source_title: Aqueous-phase mechanism for secondary organic aerosol formation from isoprene
relationships.source_authors: Marais, E. A., Jacob, D. J., Jimenez, J. L., et al.
relationships.source_quote: Isoprene SOA production is mainly contributed by two immediate gas-phase precursors, isoprene epoxydiols (IEPOX, 58 % of isoprene SOA) from the low-NOx pathway and glyoxal (28 %) from both low- and high-NOx pathways.
relationships.notes: Strong relationship between IEPOX SOA and sulfate aerosol due to acidity effects

metadata.quantitative_effect: 3.3% SOA mass yield, 58% via IEPOX pathway

relationships.description: Clouds enhance photolysis rates and OH concentration, increasing SOA formation
relationships.mechanism: Cloud layers in the troposphere influence photolysis rates (J values) through scattering and absorption of UV radiation. Clouds increase global mean OH concentration by approximately 20% through enhanced photolysis rates. Photolysis rates of J[O3], J[CH2O], and J[NO2] are enhanced by 12-13% due to clouds, leading to an 8% increase in tropospheric O3 concentrations and enhanced SOA formation.

normalized.interpretation: Cloud cover from partial (30%) to full (100%)
Effects apply to tropospheric photochemistry

conditions.original_text: Presence of ozone and water vapor

normalized.interpretation: O3 and H2O required for OH production via photolysis

relationships.source_title: Effect of clouds on photolysis and oxidants in the troposphere
relationships.source_authors: Tie, X., Madronich, S., Walters, S., Zhang, R., Rasch, P., Collins, W.
relationships.source_quote: Global mean OH concentration increases by about 20% due to the impact of clouds. Because of clouds, the globally averaged photolysis rates of J[O3], J[CH2O], and J[NO2] are enhanced in the troposphere by about 12, 13, and 13%, respectively, leading to an 8% increase in the tropospheric O3 concentrations.
relationships.notes: Cloud effects can both enhance and reduce photochemistry depending on cloud type and position

metadata.quantitative_effect: 20% increase in OH, 12-13% increase in J-values, 8% increase in O3

relationships.description: High relative humidity enables aqueous-phase SOA formation through aerosol liquid water
relationships.mechanism: High relative humidity (RH > 80%) promotes aerosol liquid water content (ALWC), enabling aqueous-phase SOA (aqSOA) formation. During high-RH periods (83.7 ± 12.5%), strong nocturnal aqueous-phase SOA formation plays a significant role in SOA production (45% of OA), with a nighttime growth rate of 0.6 µg/m³/h. Daytime aqueous-phase photochemistry also contributes 39% to OA with 0.6 µg/m³/h growth rate.

normalized.interpretation: High RH promotes aerosol liquid water content
Water-soluble organic compounds required for aqueous processing
Acidic conditions enhance aqueous-phase reactions

relationships.source_title: Multiple pathways for the formation of secondary organic aerosol in the North China Plain in summer
relationships.source_authors: Gu, Y., Huang, R.-J., Duan, J., et al.
relationships.source_quote: During the high-relative-humidity (RH; 83.7 ± 12.5 %) period, strong nocturnal aqueous-phase SOA formation (aqSOA) played a significant role in SOA production (45 % to OA), with a nighttime growth rate of 0.6 µg/m³/h.
relationships.notes: Aqueous-phase processing is particularly important during monsoon and high-humidity periods

metadata.quantitative_effect: 0.6 µg/m³/h growth rate, 45% of nighttime OA

relationships.description: Cloud/fog droplets enable aqueous-phase chemistry producing dicarboxylic acids and HULIS as SOA
relationships.mechanism: Cloud and fog droplets provide an aqueous medium for chemical reactions of water-soluble organic compounds. Aqueous-phase processing produces dicarboxylic acids (e.g., oxalic acid) and humic-like substances (HULIS) that remain in the particle phase upon droplet evaporation. aqSOA might contribute almost as much mass as gasSOA to the total SOA budget, with highest contributions from biogenic VOC emissions in the presence of anthropogenic NOx at high RH and cloudiness.

normalized.interpretation: Cloud or fog droplets provide aqueous medium
Near-saturation RH for cloud/fog formation
Glyoxal, methylglyoxal, and other WSOC required
Mixed biogenic-anthropogenic conditions maximize aqSOA

relationships.source_title: Secondary organic aerosol formation in cloud droplets and aqueous particles (aqSOA): a review
relationships.source_authors: Ervens, B., Turpin, B. J., Weber, R. J.
relationships.source_quote: aqSOA might contribute almost as much mass as gasSOA to the SOA budget, with highest contributions from biogenic emissions of volatile organic compounds (VOC) in the presence of anthropogenic pollutants (i.e. NOx) at high relative humidity and cloudiness.
relationships.notes: Particularly relevant for monsoon climate regions with frequent cloud/fog events

relationships.description: Monoterpene oxidation by OH, O3, and NO3 produces SOA accounting for ~50% of summertime fine OA
relationships.mechanism: Monoterpenes (α-pinene, limonene, myrcene) are oxidized by OH radicals during daytime and by O3 and NO3 radicals at night. The oxidation produces semi-volatile products including pinonic acid, pinic acid, and MBTCA that partition to the particle phase. Monoterpene SOA accounts for approximately 50% of summertime fine organic aerosol, with NOx processing enhancing SOA mass production.

normalized.interpretation: Emissions from coniferous and deciduous vegetation
Either daytime OH pathway or nighttime O3/NO3 pathway
Nighttime oxidation by O3 and NO3 radicals
Anthropogenic NOx enhances monoterpene SOA formation

relationships.source_title: Monoterpenes are the largest source of summertime organic aerosol in the southeastern United States
relationships.source_authors: Zhang, H., Yee, L. D., Lee, B. H., et al.
relationships.source_quote: Our results suggest that secondary OA (SOA) from monoterpene oxidation accounts for approximately half of summertime fine OA in Centreville, AL, a forested area in the southeastern United States influenced by anthropogenic pollution.
relationships.notes: NOx enhances monoterpene SOA formation through anthropogenic-biogenic interactions

relationships.description: Solar zenith angle modulates UV intensity and photochemical activity with 3-5x seasonal variation
relationships.mechanism: Solar zenith angle determines the intensity and spectral composition of UV radiation reaching the surface, directly affecting photolysis rates and OH radical production. Lower zenith angles (summer, midday) result in higher UV intensity and enhanced photochemistry. Seasonal variation in solar zenith angle creates 3-5x variation in photochemical activity between summer and winter, affecting SOA formation rates accordingly.

normalized.interpretation: Clear sky allows maximum UV penetration
normalized.inferred_reason: Clear sky typically means cloud cover < 30%

normalized.interpretation: Solar zenith angle variation depends on latitude

relationships.source_title: Multiple pathways for the formation of secondary organic aerosol in the North China Plain in summer
relationships.source_authors: Gu, Y., Huang, R.-J., Duan, J., et al.
relationships.source_quote: The photochemical pathway is the most important under high-Ox conditions. The efficient SOA formation from photochemistry (Ox-initiated SOA) dominated the daytime (65 % to OA).
relationships.notes: Diurnal and seasonal patterns of photochemistry directly affect PM2.5 formation

metadata.quantitative_effect: 3-5x variation in photochemical SOA production between seasons

relationships.description: NOx modulates SOA formation pathways: low-NOx favors IEPOX, high-NOx favors MPAN pathway
relationships.mechanism: NOx (NO + NO2) modulates SOA formation through multiple pathways: (1) NO converts RO2 to HO2 and HO2 to OH, recycling radicals and enhancing oxidation; (2) Under high-NOx conditions, isoprene oxidation proceeds via the MPAN pathway producing SOA; (3) Under low-NOx conditions, IEPOX pathway dominates isoprene SOA formation. NOx decrease leads to 7% increase in isoprene SOA (favors low-NOx pathway), while SO2 decrease leads to 35% decrease in isoprene SOA.

normalized.interpretation: Two distinct pathways depending on NOx level
ISOPO2 + HO2 pathway produces IEPOX
ISOPO2 + NO pathway produces MPAN

relationships.source_title: Aqueous-phase mechanism for secondary organic aerosol formation from isoprene
relationships.source_authors: Marais, E. A., Jacob, D. J., Jimenez, J. L., et al.
relationships.source_quote: Isoprene SOA concentrations increase as NOx emissions decrease (favoring the low-NOx pathway for isoprene oxidation), but decrease more strongly as SO2 emissions decrease (due to the effect of sulfate on aerosol acidity and volume).
relationships.notes: Complex NOx-VOC-SOA interactions determine optimal emission control strategies

metadata.quantitative_effect: 34% NOx decrease → 7% isoprene SOA increase; 48% SO2 decrease → 35% isoprene SOA decrease

relationships.description: Sulfate aerosol enhances isoprene SOA formation through acidity and volume effects
relationships.mechanism: Sulfate aerosol enhances isoprene SOA formation through two mechanisms: (1) increasing aerosol acidity which catalyzes IEPOX reactive uptake, and (2) providing aerosol volume for partitioning. Strong relationship exists between IEPOX SOA and sulfate aerosol. Reducing SO2 emissions by 48% leads to 35% decrease in isoprene SOA, representing a factor of 2 co-benefit for PM2.5 from SO2 emission controls.

normalized.interpretation: Highly acidic conditions catalyze IEPOX uptake
IEPOX from isoprene oxidation required
ALWC needed for aqueous-phase IEPOX uptake

relationships.source_title: Aqueous-phase mechanism for secondary organic aerosol formation from isoprene
relationships.source_authors: Marais, E. A., Jacob, D. J., Jimenez, J. L., et al.
relationships.source_quote: Observations show a strong relationship between IEPOX SOA and sulfate aerosol that we explain as due to the effect of sulfate on aerosol acidity and volume. Reducing SO2 emissions decreases sulfate and isoprene SOA by a similar magnitude, representing a factor of 2 co-benefit for PM2.5 from SO2 emission controls.
relationships.notes: Important for understanding co-benefits of SO2 emission controls on organic aerosol

missing_info: Quantitative J-values (photolysis rate coefficients) specific to Hanoi/Vietnam conditions; Local measurements of OH radical concentrations in tropical Southeast Asia; Specific SOA yields for tropical biogenic VOC mixtures; Cloud optical depth measurements for monsoon conditions

issues_found: Several conditions remain qualitative due to lack of specific thresholds in source papers
NOx regime (low/high) lacks quantitative definition in sources
Precursor availability conditions are inherently qualitative
Some inferred thresholds marked with inferred=true flag
